articles.headline: A Dance Between Dealer and Carmaker on Lifting Sales
articles.snippet: Kia, BMW and Nissan have encouraged dealers to buy cars, raising sales, then offer the virtually new vehicles as used models, company memos show.
articles.abstract: Kia, BMW and Nissan have encouraged dealers to buy cars, raising sales, then offer the virtually new vehicles as used models, company memos show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Auto sales hit an all-time high last year in the United States, and many analysts expect another record this year.

articles.headline: U.S. Textile Industry Turns to Tech as Gateway to Revival
articles.snippet: An M.I.T.-led research and product development project is trying to bring clothes into the digital age and make textiles a high-tech industry.
articles.abstract: An M.I.T.-led research and product development project is trying to bring clothes into the digital age and make textiles a high-tech industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warwick Mills shows the kind of innovative know-how common among American textile companies that have survived the fierce global competition of recent years.

articles.headline: Outraged by Kansas Justices’ Rulings, Republicans Seek to Reshape Court
articles.snippet: The State Senate has passed a bill to authorize impeachment of justices based on their decisions, and conservatives hope to unseat four in the fall elections.
articles.abstract: The State Senate has passed a bill to authorize impeachment of justices based on their decisions, and conservatives hope to unseat four in the fall elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Washington is locked in partisan warfare over control of the Supreme Court. But it is hardly the only place. Look at the states, where political attacks on judicial decisions are common and well-financed attack ads are starting to jar the once-sleepy elections for State Supreme Court seats.

articles.headline: Jobs and Wages Notch Gains as the Economy Tries to Heal
articles.snippet: “This is close to a Goldilocks scenario,” one analyst said, pointing out that hiring and wage gains were strong, but not too strong, as the economy continues to heal.
articles.abstract: “This is close to a Goldilocks scenario,” one analyst said, pointing out that hiring and wage gains were strong, but not too strong, as the economy continues to heal.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of economic desperation, American workers are finally regaining some of the ground they lost in the last decade’s recession and the pallid recovery that followed.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Neil Irwin

articles.headline: Hedi Slimane’s Dangerous Legacy
articles.snippet: The fashion world is suffering from short-termism on both the creative and corporate sides.
articles.abstract: The fashion world is suffering from short-termism on both the creative and corporate sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: And so the worst-kept secret in fashion has been confirmed: Hedi Slimane, the creative and image director of Yves Saint Laurent, has left the brand. Given the strength of the rumors of his departure that have been circulating since January, this may go down as the most anticlimactic fashion announcement ever made.

articles.headline: A Valeant Boo-Boo May Portend Bigger Errors
articles.snippet: As investors look for the release of the drug maker’s annual report, it has already found one error and warned of “additional accounting adjustments.”
articles.abstract: As investors look for the release of the drug maker’s annual report, it has already found one error and warned of “additional accounting adjustments.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the five months since Valeant’s board established a committee to examine the company’s accounting practices, it has turned up one $58 million error.

articles.headline: A Gay, Latino Partner Tests Goldman’s Button-Down Culture
articles.snippet: The Wall Street giant is trying to change its public image and be thought of as a tech company. No one is more central to this effort than Martin Chavez.
articles.abstract: The Wall Street giant is trying to change its public image and be thought of as a tech company. No one is more central to this effort than Martin Chavez.
articles.lead_paragraph: R. Martin Chavez possesses the light-filled office of a Goldman Sachs partner, with a sweeping view of the Statue of Liberty. But what sets his office apart is the gallery of objects and books arrayed behind the desk.
